##Letter from London: Calmness is a curse

World-views

Introduction to the function, re-understanding the world

This is a letter from London.

The writer is an old friend in England, from Wuhan.

Like she said, it's like a migratory bird that can't return to its nest.

![img](data:image/jpeg;base64,)
Black Goat. Concertina. Smoke.

The little girl in the white dress stood up from the center of the stage. Older people take off their black masks. The curtain was lifted. The ocean-scented rain diffused from the mixed music. Dancers release intense emotions in spontaneous body areas. Temptation, falling, lust, hatred, forgiveness. Lovers Walk Barefoot through seated assemblies; they embrace and kiss as if they are standing on the summit of a false mountain —— One, two, three, hop! And fell to the ground in a hug. They laughed, I laughed.

JIG, Jig. As if spinning is attached to the etheric shirt, umbrella skirt like mushrooms, rain down, they grow bravely. The river soaked my feet. The darkness hides my laughter. I looked at the whirling shadows on the white screen; the light was warm yellow, and for a moment I felt as if I had met a God.

The director's choreography has a lot of improvisation, he said in a question and answer session after the performance; William Blake often talks about innocence and imagination, and people who remain innocent see a world of infinite imagination. The world, carefree and fascinating. In the final scene of the dance, the blower goes, bloom, yellow smoke, cold wind on my face, I feel so happy.

9:30, walking in the dark, I'm texting with my phone. I told him back home that I saw a great dance show. Street lamps replaced the Daytime Sun, and people began to forget to pray to the Gods for dawn. I looked out at the night-life crowd on the street, and there was not a single Asian face.

After dinner, my Chinese friend told me to go home early in the evening after the performance. I felt a Pang of moral censorship about my immersive happiness. Click on a friend circle, open group chat, online forums, social networking sites, Chinese characters are assembled to discuss the same ongoing events as the diversity of the Internet age, reaching a highly adjustable unity at this moment.

I feel a little guilty. My Circle of friends has not been updated since January 1st. The silent circle of friends seems to have shaped me into a freehand bystander. Mean, selfish, indifferent. You don't even have to use complicated logic to come up with these rigid words. Young happiness also evolves into misery because of this powerful sense of powerlessness. The shame, the fear, the unspeakable anger that torments me. Since the outbreak, I haven't slept until four or five in the morning. In the dark, every hour to pick up a mobile phone, the flight mode to 4g, see the scientific analysis of epidemics, prevention and control measures, people's livelihood issues, medical layout.

I'm from Wuhan. This is the closest I've ever come to a social event. And I'm in London. Aside from the eight-hour time difference, what's more important is the psychological bias. I can't even click on the list of companies that have banned international flights to China. I haven't shed a tear since the outbreak. When people panic, a tsunami occurs in the "event field" . I need a calm mind, like a machine, to extract accurate information from the vast network of information, make feasible plans, and then slowly support Wuhan's family, relatives, friends, and consoling Chinese students in London who are anxious about the outbreak. I am like a migratory bird, because of the failure to return to the nest in time, had to exhaust all efforts, every tree and Bush.

On January twenty-two, I had lunch in a restaurant, two Chinese girls at a nearby table talked loudly about the relationship between the outbreak of new coronavirus pneumonia and a market called south China seafood wholesale market. In foreign countries, in public suddenly heard people mention "Wuhan" , let me feel some unexpected. Finally, I don't have to talk about "East L. " , "Wu da Sakura" and "hot and dry noodles" over and over again. "South China Seafood Market" ? I am a little unfamiliar with the term, after thinking about it, it seems to have been there to buy crabs.

On January twenty-three, a foreign friend asked me how my family was doing. I don't like to talk too much about privacy, so I answered "thank you for your concern. ". After class, when I got home, I turned on my computer to quickly check the official Chinese web site and flipped through several pages of articles in the public accounts. Having solved the epistemological problem of "COVID-19 pneumonia" , I began to list defensive measures such as masks, alcohol, possible miracle drugs, effective food and emergency supplies. My parents got up at six o'clock and I spoke to them at ten o'clock London time. They said with ease that everything was fine, that everything was ready, and that they promised not to go out during the Spring Festival. I started losing sleep. I fell asleep at 4:00 a.m. The next morning I had to get up before nine to go to class.

January twenty-four, New Year's Eve. Chinese friends began to care for each other. People who don't see each other, who do see each other, communicate their concerns about the epidemic in different ways. After an absent-minded dinner, I began a wider search for news of the outbreak. Circle of Friends, information group, Portal site, all kinds of forums. Like reading a scientific article, I was constantly scanning through all the information I could get. Popular Science, investigation, controversy. Information is exploding, growing geometrically. I was like a tiny, billowy insect, huddled before a computer screen, holding my breath; as if slightly lost the balance I was trying to maintain, I would follow the current, buried in the waves. In the face of the epidemic of chain reaction, individual heroism becomes meaningless romance. What else can I do but silence.

On January twenty-five, old fan asked me to dinner and I said I needed to calm down. At her urging, I purchased an N95 surgical mask online. It took three days for the package to arrive, and I didn't even have the energy to open it. It was just that the package was there, and there was some psychological comfort: I finally had a common bond with my family in Wuhan. The ease of ordinary life in London makes it impossible to capture the alienation of Wuhan's traffic-control residents. I remind my family to stock up on food and basic medical supplies that have been out of the house for a long time. Also told not to take seriously the severity of the epidemic Wuhan friends try not to go out. I even offered to let him burn a pillar of Network Electron Incense. The first reaction of mankind to a sudden and difficult situation is a superstition without question of cause and effect.

Over the next few days, time began to kink into a ball of thread. The foreign students politely asked me if I was OK, I said everything is OK. Chinese students asked me how Wuhan is doing, I said everything is fine. Old Fan asked me to dinner, and I've been putting it off for days, isolating myself by writing papers. On the one hand, being alone allows me to gather more objective information, analyze the trend of the epidemic, and make defense plans for my family in Wuhan. On the other hand, I need to understand the situation of the people in China at this time from a psychological perspective, to determine what social problems, in addition to medical care, might affect the lives of family members.

I am not a sociology scholar, not enough theoretical knowledge, but in the face of the epidemic, because of the care of family and friends, Miss Home, let me become an expert in social issues. My enemy is not a physical thing, but a mutated, highly contagious, deadly virus that learned to live without symptoms. I have the courage to fight, but I don't have the strength to crush them. Fan repeatedly asked me about my condition through Wechat, let me have something to say to her. She is so weak girls, because I know what is a first to carry their own people, this time also for me to share and become strong. Still, I said, everything's fine. In front of the people I love, I'm a childish crybaby. But in the face of disease, I don't enjoy weakness. Even when an individual's internalization swings like an ekg of a dying patient, when people look at you and say, are you all right? I respond with a carefree smile, I'm fine, thank you.

COVID-19 pneumonia continues to spread indiscriminately in daily life, and the keyword "COVID-19 pneumonia" proliferates in communications and media. The virus expands from disease to an abstraction, like an index, revealing many aspects of the broader social fabric that are ignored by the busy routines of ordinary days. In the same way that realism looks for differences in things, people from different backgrounds of society begin to speak out against many social phenomena.

On the one hand, the medical professionals, social workers at the grass-roots level to maintain a rational and professional in the front line of the fight against the epidemic, to perform their duties; on the other hand, the public can not get a sincere answer because of the unknown developments are dismayed. "New coronavirus pneumonia" like a runaway horse, from the eight law attack, trying to break down the Chinese society's physical and Psychological Line of Defense. Preparation never catches up with change. If you want to beat the virus, you have to keep up with it, beat it.

On February 4th, the Shelter Hospital was almost finished. On February 5, patients with mild pneumonia were admitted for treatment. As the number of people who have been cured gradually exceeds the number of deaths, there seems to be a good turn of events. Meanwhile, on February 1st a Chinese schoolgirl in Sheffield, England, was attacked by locals for wearing a mask; on the same day Der Spiegel, a German weekly, branded its cover of the new coronavirus story "made in China" ; and on February 5th, the Vancouver newspaper, the province, reported the COVID-19 as a "Chinese virus. ". The world's citizens no longer seem to be divided by jet LAG; an epidemic erases geography and hurls itself at China as it struggles with the virus.

On February th, my circle of friends posted the same keyword in seconds. People are angry, they're scared, they're angry, they're powerless. I have always believed that actions speak louder than words, and I am eager to find a way to resolve the conflict in the In & Out of this incident. But this time, I failed. I was ashamed that I had not been able to engage in a witty rebuttal. Unseemly Coolness is indifference. Selective neutrality becomes a kind of escape from criticism. I was frustrated that I couldn't The Wrestler myself again. Once upon a time, we recite the analects of Confucius, a gentleman should cultivate himself, Qi family, governance, peace under heaven. I asked myself, even if full of wisdom, well-read books, a pen, really can be healed by the virus to hurt the lives of a thousand holes?

In the theater, the foreigners around me were kissing cheek to cheek. One of them jokingly said, watch out for the infection. The other man replied gravely, it's not funny. I sat down beside them, tears welling up in my eyes. As I watched the play, I looked at the spinning dresses on the stage and tried to hypnotize myself. The little girl in the white lace dress looked like an angel, innocent, light and carefree. Since the outbreak, I finally hide myself in the dark, like a thief do not want to be found, the first time with a trace of the imagination of hope, smiled.

At night, I walk home. My heart is as the sound of the wind in the dead of night. I told him that I had seen a great play, with rain of music, and that my soul had met the gods. On Weekdays, I always complain that the day is too short, there is still a lot to be done. Today, I just want time to stop. Back home, I mechanically opened the computer, and began to browse the real-time News, query keywords. At ten o'clock in the evening, I reported to my parents on time that I was safe. It was a long day, and I was exhausted, but I couldn't sleep until 5 a.m.

Xin Wu

Written in London

Go to "discover"-"take a look" browse "friends watching"
